data.text: Bicycle Touring with Dynamo Hub, Rim Bottle Dynamo, Solar Chargers or..?
When you tour what do you use to keep your electronics (phone, gps, lights, etc) charged? Dynohub, rim bottle charger (similar to the new Pedal cell), solar charger, or what?

data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: What do you you use to charge that or do you hotel/camp with electric power ever night?
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: this specific one takes like 2 hours or less to fully charge, and it has 26k mah which is relatively fast and a lot of power compared to other banks. i would leave it charging when i would stop for food at restaurants/gas stations while keeping an eye on it, even if i stopped for just 15 minutes at the store it would be enough to charge a decent amount. i came across a lot of parks or public buildings with outlets where i liked to take long breaks and occasionally a warmshowers or hotel to charge everything overnight
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: thanks
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: That's a very good price, compared to what I paid for noname stuff just last year. PD prices are really coming down. My planned strategy was to charge my 20 Ah powerbank while I was having lunch at some roadside eatery. At 100 W charging, one hour brings it up to 80% from 0 in an hour. Or 20-100%. The best made plans of mice and men! Fast food joints here in Sweden don't have mains power outlets for patrons anymore, just puny 10 W USB-A outlets. Pathetic! So I ended up having to sit in campground kitchens to kick the timer-controlled toaster outlet every 10 minutes. Boring! For this coming season, I've got a Pedalcell dynamo. It's far superior to all the hub generators if you're slow (like me!).
data.author: Torsten Lif

data.text: Extremely rare to be without access to mains power at least every couple/three days. I also have a small (right sized) cache battery to supplement when necessary but rarely use.
data.author: Russ McCoy

data.text: Anger. Also outlets on the side of gas stations. Used a solar charger too.
data.author: Ricky Rainone Jr.

data.text: I‚Äôm planning a cross country tour for next year. I used a dynohub in the past but unfortunately my new touring recumbent has a disc brake on the front so I can‚Äôt rebuild the hub for the new bike. My brother who is traveling with me is investigating the Pedal cell. I have a smaller solar panel I will be trying on some smaller tours this year.
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: Anker solar panel and power bank. A super fast charger that fills my phone in 15 minutes. Any petrol station or shop has outlets. Churches pretty easy to keep power.
data.author: Hekta Burnz

data.text: I have the PedalCell. Between that and a spare battery, you should be fine, though obviously you'll need to make sure you cycle many hours a day, if you rely on it. It can generate between 350-600mah per hour, depending on your speed
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: Yes, I do use the Voltaic batteries. The Anger is my back up.
data.author: Lukey Nuthmann

data.text: Have a Goal Zero power bank that I use mainly. Do have a dynohub on my touring bike that I can use when I am on that bike also.
data.author: Curtis Bunton

data.text: I have an Anker 20,000mAh power bank or I use my Goal Zero Nomad 7. They both charge at about the same rate but the Anker is smaller so I‚Äôve used that lately.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: I charge a power bank with a dynamo hub, and then recharge all my devices overnight
data.author: Jason Roussel

data.text:
A big blue solar charger and a 20k milliamp battery bank: this kept two cell phones, GoPro charged everyday and some other devices also. Even when I had the option to plug-in, I didn't bother because it was inconvenient to change my charging routine. https://bigblue-tech.com/products/28w-sunpower-solar-charger https://www.amazon.com/Portable-Charger-Anker-PowerCore-20100mAh/dp/B00X5RV14Y/ref=asc_df_B00X5RV14Y/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=198094100392&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=2075575870165793176&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=m&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9032876&hvtargid=pla-378837702449&psc=1
BigBlue 28W SunPower Solar Charger
bigblue-tech.com
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: I bring portable charger chargers and a small solar charger... but sometimes the most valued thing in my kit is this bad boy because I can charge my phone and 2 lights anytime I'm stopped somewhere with electric:
data.author: Lindsey Hamma

data.text: You might take a little time and look back on this and other FB touring/bikepacking pages. This question is asked and answered often. I have invested quite a bit of time looking into this issue as I often find myself days away from electricity. A solar panel has worked well for many years. I use Goal Zero, but there are many others. On tours with long climbs, 4, 5 hours, and longer dyno hubs do not put out enough power at such slow speeds. Even on cloudy days the battery pack and my phone are fully charged at the end of the day. Panel on rear rack
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I plug into the mains at night‚Ä¶.
data.author: Steve Copeland

data.text: A couple of years ago I was 3 days from any mains, high in the Andes. The inhabitants of the 4 hut village were very impressed with Google Earth.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I have a large power bank for that sort of duration, but then I only have a phone and a Garmin 1030 to charge. My power bank will do a week of charging for them.
data.author: Steve Copeland

data.text: We have a dynohub but only really use it to charge the wahoo gps. The other stuff is charged from the mains when we find a place to charge or our solar panels.
data.author: Simeon Pang

data.text: Power bank. Unless you are spending weeks at a time without access to power, the solar and Dyno chargers don't make sense.
data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: I like a solar panel
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: Anker 15 Watt dual USB solar charger and an Anker battery bank.
data.author: Daren Eaken

data.text: Thanks for all the good input‚Ä¶.will try my solar panel and available outlets on my 12 day tour this fall as preps for next year.
data.author: Ed Chimahusky

data.text: get rid of all the electronic clutter.its thoroughly unnecessary and contributes to climate change.use a map and compass.lighting is always on hand if you have a dynamo hub and led lights.
data.author: Manfred Schiller

data.text:
There is a lot of info about electronics on Alee‚Äôs www.cyclingabout.com Dynamohubs are limited by design. I would check www.pedalcell.com/reviews If you go solar: I would take one with two usb outlets and >20W It will be useful to charge fast, and when cloudy.
